title: Chrysler Town and Country Stow 'n Go Latch

description.text:
One of the stow-n-go latches on my wife's 2005 Town and Country van broke. I looked at purchasing a replacement part, and the least expensive I found was around $30 from a questionable source. Rather than risk that (or pay twice that at a dealership) I decided to print a replacement. I searched Thingiverse, but didn't find the part. I decided to draw up the part myself. This thing is the result.

I printed it first in PLA to test the fit and work out any issues. I was planning to print the final in ABS. I made one attempt to print it in ABS and it didn't turn out to my satisfaction. I printed the part vertically (with supports) and the ABS curled up on the overhangs. The ABS part is functional, but looks a little sloppy. I suppose that doesn't really matter, since the part is hidden 99% of the time when it's in use, but I'm somewhat OCD at times. I installed the PLA part and it's been doing it's duty well since.

title: First scan of Rich with Sense

description.text:
This is a full scale scan of me done on the first night of using my Cubify Sense scanner.  It was only cleaned and trimmed in the Sense software.  Ideally, I would take this file and do some sculpting to work on the definition of features.  It turned out pretty decent.  
My experience is that the Sense scanner is good for people. Not super precise but easy to use on people. The short cable is an issue, but you can use an extender. If you want a full 360, you best bet is a turntable or windows table if you have one or some "rig" for carrying your laptop around while you scan like one of those cigarette ladies at clubs from old movies on TCM.  
Comparing it to Kinect with Recontructme, the Sense software is more complete in that you can easily edit within the software and output a watertight mesh.  
The color output is not precise enough to be useful other than on large objects. Something like a cereal box will look like you have cataracts. People are ok, but I did not get it for the color, I needed a low cost easy to use solution that does a good job on people.  
I am thinking of getting some +2, +3 reading glasses like people have used on the Kinect and Carmine and see if it helps with small objects.
Unless you have a giant printer, you will need to scale to fit. Of course, if you have a CNC, feel free to scan this old man full scale. Otherwise it should be watertight and ready to go.

comments.text: Per cubify, the PLY file has color info.

title: Mini Drum Sander
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a mini drum sander that I'm working on that will allow me to sand small parts with just the power of my impact driver/hand drill.

The design is centered around using a 1/4 sheet to optimize paper usage. The sheet is wrapped around the drum and then a wedge of some sort (still need to figure out the wedge a bit) is shoved into the slot in the drum to hold it taut.

Parts:
2 Walls
2 Bearing Clamps
2 Bearings 1/2"ID 1-1/8"OD x 5/16 thickness
1 Shelf
1 Drum
1 Hex Drive
A ton of various length 10-32 or 10-24 bolts and appropriate washers
A (recommending plywood) base to screw the walls to

Current concerns:
1- I've left 5-thou tolerances in most places which I'm hoping is the right amount for no slop, but also, if things are a bit off level between the drum and the bearings, one could strategically place some blue-tape around parts of the bearings to raise one side by a few thou to help level as needed.
2- Although using the hex-drive is handy as it means you don't have to buy a new motor to run this tool, I'm not sure if having to use one hand to control the drill-driver will make using this too hard.
a- I have therefore made the driver-part a plug that goes into the drum with a large hex-insert so that if needed, new drive mechanisms can be designed.
3- I envision putting the table into place and then locking it down against the walls from the sides in the slot. However, this doesn't allow for micro-adjust. Suggestions on developing a micro-adjust mechanism are welcome.

comments.text: New photo added showing tolerances checked and also that the hex-drive attachment actually fits into an impact driver and locks (it does).

title: Miniture Thomas Train Track
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My son received some miniature Thomas train engines as a gift. These are smaller than the standard Brio and whatnot that run on the wooden tracks. I don't know what type of track they are supposed to run on. It appears that the track has some sort of T-bar in the middle so that the train stays on the track.

I figured if he had some train engines, he needed a track to run them on. Rather than looking into purchasing proper tracks, I decided to print them. I looked on Thingiverse and did not find any tracks which looked like they would work, so I decided to draw them up myself. This thing is the result.

I did not add the T-bar which I suspect it in the official purchased version. There is a single straight bar in the middle of the track which the bracket on the bottom of the engines fits around to steady the train. I just wanted something simple and quick so he would be able to properly play with his new train. This thing is a 45 degree curved section of track. That means that eight of them will complete a circle (360mm diameter). At this point, I've not considered drawing up different configurations. The trains run nice and smoothly around the circle. Well enough for now (my son is two and not able yet to lay out the tracks himself).

description.text:
This model is a replacement for the Radio Shack DIY Drone Starter Kit (https://www.radioshack.com/products/radioshack-diy-drone-starter-kit?variant=21420195781). After a few flights, by drone body became weak and the drone became unstable. I designed this new airframe to support the electronics in the kit.

The battery, PCB, and motors all friction fit in my model. I did have to bend some of the LED wires to allow the PCB to fit in the supports. This does not affect function. The 3D printed airframe is lighter than the stock plastic one that comes in the kit. This difference in Mass greatly affects flying, enabling longer battery life and quicker ascents. The airframe is designed to be small and lightweight. There is a hole in the bottom of the airframe as well as thin prop support rods to aid in this goal.

See the printer settings section to aid in replicating this project.

For more information on this and other projects, see http://08milluz.com.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed this with ABS on my Makerbot 2X. The dimensions of the model account for the slight shrinking. Printing with ABS should result in a friction fit. If you use PLA, the fit should still be pretty good, but you may want to shrink the model 2% or use hot glue to hold the electronics and motors in. I printed with 2 shells.

I printed with HIPS supports and raft. See post printing for more details on how to clean up the airframe.

Remove supports

Most of the HIPS supports easily broke away and the raft came right off. To finish the model, I did let it sit over night in D-Limonene. This process removed a few of the small supports in the corners of the model. It is not necessary, but it does improve the final print quality.

Potrei avere il gcode che include già il CFOG? così da avere un esempio tangibile su cui studiare il procedimento.

Luca.

description.text:
Updated 12/11/2017: Short version had a very small lip on both sides which would affect the print. I removed the lip on both sides so it prints better and looks cleaner.

I have a Anker PowerCore 20100 and the biggest issue was that there was no way to easily hold cables without wrapping them around the battery which was far to messy for my OCD.

I designed this simple holder and it is a perfect fit! I have printed it in Hatchbox PLA and TPU so far and the fit is remarkable. The PLA may be snug but I prefer that so it holds on tightly and does not slide off.

Let me know how you guys like it!

This was just a quick scan I did with the Sense handheld scanner with two of my kids sitting on the floor and me just sitting in a chair. I made no attempt to scan around them so this model only looks good from one direction.  It was so simple to do with the Sense scanner and software that it will make for some some capturing of life.  
If you look at the back of this file, you will see that it has a lot of stuff filled in.  This was all done automatically by the software.  
12-2-13 I just upload a decimated version of the file to reduce the triangle count and file size.
Scanned people with a Sense scanner.  You will need to scale down if you actually print this out.  It should be watertight already.

description.text:
Had a couple instances where the filament jumped off the spool and wrapped itself around the holder and kinked up so I thought I would make a spool guide that can prevent it from happening again.

There are 2 guides in the STL file, spaced closely together so they print a bit faster.

I planned to just superglue these to the back of my Flash Forge Creator Pro and Flash Forge Creator X and Replicator 2 but I ended up using one as a test on my Mono Price Select Mini. (See included Pics)

It works great! The "eyelet" slips through the "slot" and is removable, while retaining the ability to float back and forth in the slot as it tracks the way the filament is wrapped on the spool.

Haven't had any instances in several weeks of filament hopping off the spool and I've put nearly 300 hours of use on the printer after installing the guide (so it's been tested pretty thoroughly)

Printer:

Any printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I do insert supports in the eyelet.

It can be printed using any type of filament in any printer. The ones in the pictures were printed on my Flash Forge Creator Pro using Hatchbox Black ABS and were then put through the Acetone Vapor Bath so it strengthens the main part a LOT and gives it a lustrous finish (which makes it difficult to properly photograph it to show detail)

If you want to do the Acetone Vapor Bath...

Find an old scented Candle jar which has been used, scrape out any remaining candle wax, place a napkin/paper towel in it leaning up one wall inside the jar.

Pour about a cap full of 100% Acetone Nail Polish Remover onto the napkin

Place a piece of Aluminum foil (Aluminium for those blokes across the pond) onto the napkin and place the part on the foil ensuring it isn't touching the acetone-soaked napkin/paper towel

Put the lid on the jar and set it to the side while you're putzing around printing other stuff.

When it is close to having the sheen you want, remove it GENTLY as the acetone has melted the plastic a bit...(that's what you're going for in the first place but, until the acetone evaporates from the part it is still weak so be careful)

Place the part aside and let it sit for an hour or so to completely to "air out". You'll find it's 50% (or more) stronger than the freshly-printed part, and is very smooth

This thing is a customizable lighthouse form generator.

It was created as a project for me to learn about catenary curves (the curve that a free-hanging chain takes, and used in many built forms to efficiently deal with gravity).

You can customize: the diameter of the top, bottom and hollow centre; the number of courses (layers); plus some other shape tweaks.

The thing can be rendered as a full stack of courses, or each course can be rendered individually.

Each course is a slice of a cone, as this better matches the way real lighthouses were constructed. The upper and lower edges of each course lie on a perfect catenary.

I was intrigued by the the multitude of shapes and shear complexity of a natural snowflake as photographed using an electron microscope. Thus, I decided to try my hand at a childhood favorite; making a snowflake for the holidays. I used only the natural angles created my water crystals that are tetrahedrally bonded to form this snowflake.
Print and be merry. Happy holidays.

This model is intended to be produced using full external supports, with the extra boundary layers set to zero.
For best results print at a slower feed rate as the print is quite intricate.
I also recommend making sure you clean your print bed before printing to insure good adherence of your print material.
Then print using your filament of choice.
And then to finish the ornament you can pass a ribbon or fiber through one of the three provided through holes.

This was a gift I came up with after a long day of brainstorming.
It is an led infinity mirror heart.

Video of finished project working: https://youtu.be/gi1x0VNohWc

This idea originally started off a bit more simple, I couldn't resist expanding the concept. Originally it was only suppose to have 1 led strip, but there were some cool patterns you couldn't do unless two strips were stacked...And then I added on more..

Materials needed:
-Arduino micro.
-12in x 12in two way mirror(reflective on both sides.)
-12in x 12in standard glass mirror.
-3v DC rumble motor(for heart vibration).
-Hand soldered pcb for connecting components.(1 transistor was added (2n222 for motor power)).
-2 strips of 60LED per meter neopixels(RGBW).
-1 RGBW neopixel for small heart indicator.
-IR distance sensor (For detecting when someone is in front of mirror).

Materials used for assembly:
-Hot glue.
-Super glue.
-Double sided tape.
-Black paint.(used to prevent light bleed through on 2 way mirror)

Please leave feedback or questions if you have any!

Enjoy!

Updated!!!
This is (now) a design for the Raspberry Pi Zero. There are three types of "Fire Stone" covers and several variants of each. The "1Piece" and the 3 piece (A,B,and choose which C you want). The multi-spot designs were for an (optional) pushbutton, and one with 8 LED spaces. I had to grudgingly make a split case as assembly was just too difficult. Finally, I've made a slightly bigger version to accommodate micro-USB right angle connectors.

In the post printing section I have directions for installing Google Assistant. I've removed the AlexaPi since the reason why Amazon didn't want to publish my code is pretty clear.

Adding the rotating status lights is easy (once I found the module). I'll include a schematic and some code once complete and tested. Most of the problem is assembly.

I have left here the base for an RPi 2/3 that will fit the regular stones. They are huge however.

This project started as a search for a "displayable" case for a Raspberry Pi for an Amazon Echo/Google Home device. Finding only one or two, I then remembered the Fifth Element Stones as seen in project:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1012118

Fully props go to Imirnman and attribution, for creating the outside so realistically.

Since the stones are hollow and are JUST big enough to accommodate an RPi, I thought this would be perfect to use.

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3 AL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50%

Hardware Requirements

Hardware:
USB Sound Card (I used a Sabrent AU-MMSA)
Tiny audio amp/speaker (Adafruit PAM8302)
Tiny microphone (Adafruit MAX4466)
Raspberry Pi Zero W
IR LED (I used NTE3027 - a blowtorch 130mW out)
NPN transistor (NTE229)
560 ohm resistor
27K ohm resistor
LEDs
330 ohm resistor for each LED
TSOP328 IR Detector

Helpful:
Mini HDMI to HDMI cable and USB keyboard

USB Cables:
6 ft USB A Cable
Micro USB 2.0 On-The-Go (OTG) Cord (Kendak were the only ones I could find that go in the right direction.

Or buy a small hub, and solder to:
PP1: +5V (Red)
PP6: Gnd (Black)
PP22: USB D+ (Green)
PP23: USB D- (White)

Print:
For MiniFireStoneBase (expert)
MiniFireStoneBase, and MiniFireStoneCarrier (which are then glued together)
Cover A,B (or 2 "B's" if you need more space), and your choice of C. These can be glued together once the IR and status LED's have been installed.

For FireStoneBase (easy, lots of room)

Connections (Minimum needed for IR and 2 LEDs).

  1. Ground (6)
  2. +5 (2)
  3. GPIO 18 (12) = LED1
  4. GND (14)
  5. GPIO 23 (16) = LED2
  6. GPIO 21 (40) = IRLED
    6a. GPIO 22 (15) = IR Receiver

4 LEDs

  1. GPIO 24 (18) = LED3
  2. GPIO 25 (22) = LED4

8 LEDs

  1. GPIO 12 (32) = LED5
  2. GPIO 16 (36) = LED6
  3. GPIO 20 (38) = LED7
  4. GPIO 26 (37) = LED8

Assembly:

  1. Print the Top first (either 2,4, or 8), then start printing the Base and the Carrier. Steps 2-8 can be done while those are printing.
  2. Hot melt glue or epoxy putty the LED's in place
  3. Solder a 330 ohm resistor to each of the short legs (Cathode) of the LEDs.
  4. Tie the other end of all the resistors together along with the emitter (middle wire) of the transistor and a black wire. This is the ground plane.
  5. The base of the transistor goes to the 27Kohm resistor.
  6. The collector of the transistor goes to the short leg (Cathode) of the IRLED.
  7. The long leg of the IRLED goes to the 560ohm resistor.
  8. The other end of the 560ohm resistor connect a red wire to. This will be +5.

You'll now have the long legs of the LEDs and the other end of the 27Kohm resistor with no connections. These will all be connected to a wiring run back to the GPIO ports later.

  1. Once the Base is printed, cut the micro USB connector from the 6' cord and run that end through the base. I recommend tying a knot about 4" from the end as a strain relief. It's wise at this point to verify with a volt meter the +5v and ground connections on the cable.
  2. Solder wires to the RPi Zero using the recommended connections above. Use about 7-8 inches of wire for each connection.
  3. Solder wires the +5 and ground wires to the RPi Zero test pads. You'll want a +5 and Ground "bus" connection. If your soldering the usb connections directly to the RPi Zero, do so now.
  4. Once the Carrier is printed, you can mount the RPi Zero W to it and then glue the Carrier to the Base.
  5. Print the Joiner and the Cover.
  6. Rip apart the amplified speaker, connect it's power and ground to the buses and plug in the jack into the USB Mic and Headphone Adapter (green).
  7. Mount the speaker over one set of the speaker grill holes, then connect the speaker's +5V and ground to the bus connections.
    15 Plug the mic into the USB Mic and Headphone Adapter (pink).
  8. Glue the joiner onto the completed Top.
  9. Thread the wires through the Cover and connect them to the LEDs in the top.
  10. Connect the 6a wire to the pin 1 of the TSOP328, pin 2 the the ground bus and pin 3 to the +5V bus.

I recommend (and have written the test code around) connecting the LEDs like this:

                              1
                      5             6
                 3                       4
                      7             8
                              2

Now for the software:

Start with a fresh OS, this example is written off of:
RASPBIAN STRETCH LITE (2017-08-16)

  1. "DD" the image to the Micro SMB card, power up (with the Helpful HDMI and USB Keyboard attached.
  2. Run the "sudo raps-conifg" (turn on ssh, among other settings)
  3. Configure WiFi
  4. Run the software upgrade on your image "sudo apt-get upgrade"
  5. Run the software update on your image "sudo apt-get update"
  6. Update the firmware on the RPiZero "sudo rpi-update"

Install LIRC:

  1. "sudo apt-get install lirc"
  2. Add the following to /etc/modules:
    "lirc_dev"
    "lirc_rpi gpio_in_pin=22 gpio_out_pin=40"

Use GPIO 22 instead of 18.

  1. I then used:
    http://alexba.in/blog/2013/01/06/setting-up-lirc-on-the-raspberrypi/

We'll later use Google Assistant to send the CLI command: "irsend SEND_ONCE your remote KEY_POWER"

Test that command to make sure the RPi IR LED is working correctly.

Test the LEDs:

From the CLI create the file "circleled.py" using this code if using 8 LEDs :
============chomp===============
import RPi.GPIO as GPIO
import time

chan_list = [12,36,24,37,16,38,18,32] # for 8 LEDs
GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM) # Numbers GPIOs by port
GPIO.setup(chan_list, GPIO.OUT) # Set LedPin's mode is output

for loop in chan_list:
GPIO.output(loop, GPIO.HIGH) # Set LedPin high(+3.3V) to turn on led
time.sleep(1)
GPIO.output(loop,GPIO.LOW)
GPIO.cleanup
==========chomp================

This command will test your LED install, and can be used later for Google Assistant to show each status.

The rest of the way is based on the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TIT01KGJZMU&t=116s

Configure and test sound:
(this might be broke)

  1. "nano /etc/asoundrc"
    pcm.!default {
    type hw card 1
    }
    ctl.!default {
    type hw card 1
    }

  2. "speaker-test -t wav c -2" should get you some audio out your speaker.
  3. "arecord --format=S16_LE --duration=10 --rate=16k --file-type=raw tester.raw" will record a 10 sec file and write it to the file.
  4. Play the test: "play --format=S16_LE --rate=16k tester.raw"
  5. Use "alsamixer" command to set the levels. Use F6 to change to USB and crank your levels almost to the red. Re-test in step 3.

Get your Google Secret Key:
(more coming)

Install the Google Assistant:

  1. "sudo apt-get install python3-dev python-venv"
  2. "python3 -m env venv"
  3. "env/bin/python -m pip install --upgrade pip setuptools"
  4. "sudo apt-get install git"
  5. "source env/bin/activate"
  6. "git clone https://github.com/googlesamples/assistant-sdk-python"
  7. "cp -r assistant-sdk-python/google-assistant-sdk/googlesamples/assistant/grpc /home/pi/ZeroExample"
  8. "python -m pip install --upgrade google-auth-oauthlib[tool]"
  9. "google-oauthlib-tool --client-secrets googlesecret.json --scope https://googleapis.com/auth/assistant-sdk-prototype --save --headless"
  10. Copy the URL the command provides onto your other system (it will start with https://accounts.google.com/o/oauth2"). After choosing the correct account and login in, you will get a string (the authorization code) that you can paste or type back into the RPi (using SSH into your RPi really helps here).
  11. "sudo apt-get install portaudio19-dev libffi-dev libssl-dev" (next steps each take a while)
  12. "pip install --upgrade google-assistant-grpc"
  13. cd /home/pi/ZeroExample
  14. "pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt"
  15. "pip install --upgrade -r urllib3"
  16. Test the Google Audio: "python3 -m audio_helpers"
  17. Test Google Assistant: "python3 -m pushtotalk". Ask it to "tell me a joke".

title: Timelapse Dolly controled by Smartphone App

description.text:
Excited from some Timelapse videos on YouTube, i wanted to make some Timelapses for my own.
Timelapses are working more realistic, if a think near to the camera moves slowly while recording.
My idea is to use my Android-smartphone to take the picture but also to control the movement after calcing the steps and times between the pictures. The Sourcecode für Android and Adruino is included.

The smartphone connects to this machine via bluetooth. in the wagon an arduino nano mit a accu from RC-Car is responsible for the communication with the smartphone and controls the stepper motor.
Additional 2 switches at the bottom are use by the software, to calibrate the position. In calibration mode startet on the Android, the wagon drives to the given end until a switch is closed. The Adruino programm stops the motor und starts to drive slowly into the opposite direction until the switch is releasing. The wagon is now calibrated,

The smartphone itsself is attached with a ball head joint, so you can adhust it.
I am offering a case for my smartphone MI5. Don't wonder about the open bottom, this ist made to move my smartphone in it WITH the bookcase so i have not to extract the phone every time.
This case is very simple, you can change ist so it is fitting to your phone. A 123Design file is included.

Have fun and post links to your records on YouTube!

Printer:

Wanhao 5s mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Print the top and the bottom and clue them together.
Also clue the 2 sides of the impeller after insering the bearings.
The rest can be screwed, i used mostly 3mm screws.

The aluminium rails are 20*15mm. For my project they are 2m long but you can make them shorter.

The teeth band for transporting is the same as you are using in your 3D Printer.
On both sides there are attachments to fix the ends because this project the band must not build a circle becuase the wagon itsself moves on this and it is not controlled from an external stepper.
At on end you can thighten to toothband with a screw.

The tripod connectors are only pressed into to rails but you can clue them. At the bottom there is a bolt integrated to use them on 2 tripods. But you can place the dolly directly to the ground without tripods.

author: alan0019hk

title: Cooling fan shroud for Folger Tech FT-5 stock hot end

description.text:
This is for the Folger Tech FT-5 3D printer's stock hot end. So many of the cooling fan shrouds do not fit well or are for E3D hot ends. The others I've tried either poke in so close that they get melted, of hang below the nozzle which would knock over your parts.

Print this shroud standing up so that it looks like a wine glass from the side and you won't need any supports.

Adjust the height of the throat in the big aluminum block so that the nozzle is just below the shroud. Your heater core and thermistor wires should be exiting from the left as you look at it from the front where the LCD panel is.

You will need to use the fan bracket from this project here to be able to mount it: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1856623

comments.text: The slant in the file is not sliced properly. the base that the print rests on is not sitting flat, or is not a flat face, which produces a floating print:
comments.author: Careless

comments.text: The bottom is supposed to be a 3 degree slant because of the offset from the fan bracket and the placement of the stock hot end.  If it is perfectly square then the hot end runs into the side of the cooler melting it when the wires come of of the hot end on the left as you're looking at it.  If your wires come out of the right then you can probably get rid of that 3 degree slant.
comments.author: Careless

comments.text:
Would like to print this, but there's something wrong with your file.
It doesn't place a proper initial layer, so half the base won't adhere to the bed properly.
comments.author: seabell

comments.text: The bottom is a 3 degree slant so that it moves it over to be centered around the hot end. So you need to orient it right in your slicer.  This is possible with Cura and Simplify 3D.
comments.author: seabell

comments.text:
OK.
Sorry if I sounded ungrateful - I'm not!
Got it to print, though a little rough. Seems to be one of those 'gotchas' where you need a layer cooler to do a good print - but what if you don't have one and are trying to print one?!
Currently printing the adapter. Will report back when I have the whole shebang set up and working.
Thanks for your effort!
comments.author: Sinisnear

comments.text: No no no, it's ok.  :)  It's a weird thing to make it literally on a slant.  You can try a small personal fan to cool things down.  I used a putty knife at one point to hold the curling PLA edges down.
comments.author: seabell

comments.text:
Hah!, I used a small (6") stainless ruler.
About to upload a photo of your 'product' ;-)

After printing, clean up model, rub some candle wax on the end part, slip the Outside handle part - the cylinder - over the handle and press fit.

This is the SVG by plasma2002 extruded out 1/8in and converted to STL for 3d printing.  I made this so I could print them and figured it may save some effort for other people.
The original scale is not preserved.  These are scaled to approximately fill my useful build area (160mm in X).  Smaller machines are probably out of luck.

print_settings.Notes:: If you print in a filament prone to shrinking after cooling down, like ABS, you might want to upscale the model by a fraction of a percent to compensate for shrinkage.

description.text:
Everyone keeps making the same minor variations on the same spinners, so here's something more original. For those who don't like the sharper corners, there's also a smooth variant.

This is a small spinner that uses 625zz bearings with an outer diameter of 16 mm and a thickness of 5 mm. The small size makes this especially kid-friendly, and allows adults to swing it around in one hand when holding it at one of the outer bearings.
The spanner is 9 mm size and should be functional if you either don't put too much stress on it, or have it printed in steel :)

You can fill the holes in the bearings with caps in the shape of a ‘bolt’ and ‘nut’ to greatly improve the fidgetability. Because the smaller caps are also 9 mm, you could hook up multiple of these spinners together. The nuts/bolts come in two sizes, the smaller one is 9mm, the bigger one is 10mm and is thicker, which makes it ideal for the center bearing because it allows the spinner to be placed on a flat surface while spinning.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

100% infill will make it heavier and let it spin longer. For the same reason, a dense filament like PETG is ideal (PLA also is usually heavy, although this may vary between brands). In my case, the blue PLA print is heavier than the green PETG even though they have the same infill.

The models come in multiple tolerances. The spinner itself comes in a regular version with holes that are just a tad larger than theoretically needed for the bearings, this is the one to print if you know your printer usually prints holes too small. The ‘tight’ models have a hole slightly smaller than necessary, this offers a very snug fit for the bearings if your printer is very accurate.

The nuts also come in three different tolerances, 0 is exact, 1 has 0.1 mm extra hole diameter, and 2 has 0.2 mm extra. These things are small and quick to print anyway, so you might as well print them all at once and see which one fits best.

If you print in a filament prone to shrinking after cooling down, like ABS, you might want to upscale the model by a fraction of a percent to compensate for shrinkage.

Some sanding may be required to fit the bearings and the ‘nuts and bolts’ if your print isn't perfect. Avoid using excessive force when pushing the bolts through the bearings. Ideally, the bolt axle should be exactly 5 mm thick, which will provide a snug fit without having to push hard on the bearings. You can sand the axle and check with a calliper or micrometer until it is exactly 5 mm diameter or slightly less.

2017/07/09

Replaced the models with v2 version, which should be almost perfectly balanced (if printed with 100% infill). Provided a larger end cap to be used as center cap allow spinning on a table. Also, the caps now have a better clip mechanism that snaps in place.

These holders are low-poly, easy to build "corners" that have a hidden compartment for a 0.75" or smaller diameter magnet. They're designed to hold 0.1" glass, plexiglass, acrylic, or anything you can fit in them. The models themselves are extremely easy to modify.  
Simply print the corner "hole down" and print the associated cap. Slide your magnet in (available at pretty much any hobby shop) and glue the cap on.  
I've demonstrated it here with an enclosure for my SD3. Even with cheap magnets, they're light enough to allow you to hold very large sheets of acrylic or plexi.

title: Christmas Tree (now with lamp base)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Oh Christmas Tree! Oh Christmas Tree!

Designed to be printed in is single wall vase mode. Photos show it printed in transparent green PETG.

Fairly large model 210mm dimeter by 300mm tall. Scale to fit your your printer.
Could scale the z height separately for skinnier or fatter trees.

PLEASE remember this is a non-commerical license--make for yourself or as gifts to give-away to friends and family. If you sell them, contact me and ask for a commercial license.

Study of various materials: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qexqRiBG268

ADDED: New faceted version. Lots more bling. Last two trees in video above.
ADDED: Screenshots where to find vase/spiralize mode in main 3 slicers. Faster prints yay!
UPDATE 12/21/2016--
ADDED: two files forE27 light bulb holder. "Short base" for regular LED light bulbs (see warning), and "Tall base" for specialty bulbs like the disco RGB LED bulb that makes a nice Northern Lights effect.
ADDED: Lamp base for 300mm tree.

(WARNING: triple-check the bulbs do not get warm enough to soften the holder)

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

02.mm

Infill:

0% vase mode

Notes:

I printed without base layers so I could eventually put a light inside. I used 4 brim loops at 0 distance so the first layer would stick well.

A bit of over extrusion helps the layers stick. And running a bit hotter. Run slower until you get it dialed in.

4h42m to print at 0.2mm and 100% (300mm tall). But upped the speed a bit and got them to print in about 3h45m. Varies with filament.

For E27 light attachment (short base and long base), print with three perimeters/shells at 0.2mm layers.

I found clamp work lights make a nice base of you disable and reassemble them without the clamp. And the ones I found at the big box store are UL certified.

The trunk base was designed for E27 light sockets with switches I found on Aliexpress. They are of questionable quality and Of the 10 I ordered, I had to resolder 3 of them. For low wattage LED bulbs, I think should be fine but you be your own judge and use at your own risk. Mould not trust them for anything over 10W making triple-sure they do not get warm.
I stay in shape with Onshape.

author: DCT1964

description.text:
I bought a new backpack that has MOLLE/PALS straps for attaching pouches and gear. I had extra straps that I wasn't using so I thought I would add something fun to them. For the two color prints I paused the print and switched filaments.

I'm working on several more.

** Update 30 Nov 2016
I've uploaded a part called "corner holder". Its designed to stop the hexagons from moving when you pull a drawer out. It locks into the bottom drawers in a cluster, and hooks down the back of a desk.

These are some interlocking drawers I designed to store electrical components. They lock together so you can add as many as you like, and pick them all up when moving them.

I printed them on my cacoon create 3d printer (same based on a wanhao). The draws have slots in them for dividers I am going to eventually print. The idea is you can print the draws and add dividers as needed.

If you want to print your own dividers the slots are 2mm wide and 1mm deep.

**** All the drawers edges are 2mm thick so you might want to make the bottom layer thicker otherwise the drawer bottom will sag - a certain amount of infill will help fix this.

wall thickness 0.4mm
bottom layer: 0.3mm
layer height: 0.2mm
infill: 0%

You might want to add some infill to add structural integrity - but it seems okay without it, especially when you lock multiple drawers together.

Everything seems like a good fit when I printed them. If you print them post your designs! Happy printing!

comments.text: Did you fix the fit issue that was happening on the original?  I printed out your drawers and have one of the original bases, and no go.  So, before I print your bases, I need to know if they should be scaled at all.  Cheers!

I just read a bunch of negative feedback on The Hive and how you'd better scale if you want it to work.  I appreciate the quick response though.  Finishing up the final drawer prints, and will soon be onto the long wait for all of the bases.

comments.author: malebox

comments.text: Roger that!  I was out of town this last week, and had set a 68 hour print of 4 of the bases, but I checked the camera about an hour in and realized something bad happened lol.  I was having issues before I left, so it was a fingers crossed start.  Now that I'm back, I've jumped up the resolution to 0.3 just so I can cut down on the time.  So far so good.  I may start up another week long print once my APC comes in.  I really like lower resolutions on pieces like this that I plan on showing off, but nothing is more enraging than a super long print being stopped by a brownout or flicker.

number_of_layers = 12
image_file = lithopane20131127-26144-1ob5h3m-0.dat
hole_diameter = 10

This is a form to make propellers out of standard tongue depressors.  Drill a 3/32" hole in the middle of the tongue, soak in water for about 5 minutes, then push into form.  When dry, remove from form, glue a 8.25" bamboo skewer through the hole and top off with a pony bead...or better yet...print one of your own!!!  I enjoy using my Makerbot to complement my other loves...one being teaching students about wood working. :)
Made with Autodesk Inventor.

title: Star Wars Stormtrooper Universal/Intergalactic Cellphone Charging Stand

description.text:
Star Wars fan art project: I made this because I just can't have enough Stormtrooper stuff! Can't wait for the next movie!

12/4/16 added I-phone 6 lock ( remix of 742415) to bring I-phone support!

12/1/16 revised holder-upper.stl to use less material and print much faster. Revised lockNote3.stl to print faster and lock in better.

11/29/16 Printed full scale prototype and uploaded pics. additional tweaks to come.

11/26/16 Added Samsung Galaxy Note 3 perfect fit power cord lock. Corrected previous cable tunnel bug which caused the phone to lean forward out of the cradle.

11/25/16 BUG: phone cable tunnel incorrect. corrections in process.

11/25/16 REVISED: split trooper for easier print. Corrected some problems with trooper model. Added voids to reduce material usage by 30%. Added minor mesh tweaks for easier print. Added more images to description. Added additional video with better lighting and effects. Printed and verified @ reduced scale.

11/24/16 REVISED: split into 3 parts. added flare.
Universal cellphone charging stand. Recommend infill >20, with support. Exact fit connector adapter coming soon.

Verified printable. tested @ low res miniature.(see photo)

title: Universal IOT Remote
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I enjoy playing around with home automation projects and until now have only had a web interface for most things. While this is convenient and allows me to access my various sensors and actuators using a smartphone or PC, nothing beats the speed and accessibility of a remote control -- Always on, always ready. That is the goal of this project. Something quick to pick-up that allows me to trigger/execute common tasks at the push of a button without needing to wake a pc, to unlock a phone, or even a screen.

The remote uses very little power when not in use, less than 1uA. A CR2032 can power the device for years.

Three of the buttons will not wake the uC from sleep but can be used as modifier keys similar to CTRL, ALT, and Shift. These keys combined with the fact that you can detect multiple keys pressed at once, holding keys for a period of time, etc. allows for an excessive number of possible actions you can trigger with the remote.

You can use the remote to turn on a TV, close the garage, wake a PC, send a panic text or email to relatives, turn on lights, or even as an Amazon Dash button.

This project is very much a work in progress with a long list of planned improvements and bugs to fix.

If you have any suggestions on how to improve the idea, please leave a comment.

P.S. I know the physical design is lacking but I don't have the proficiency needed with CAD software to make something more aesthetically appealing and ergonomic.

Update 11/27/2016: Uploaded a new case design. It has not been tested yet.

#include "bcm2835.h"
#include "NRFComm.h"
#include "NRFConfig.h"
#include "NRFFunctions.h"
#include "bcm2835Config.h"

#define NRF_REM_PIPE 1

int main(int argc, char **argv){

        unsigned char NRFStatus = 0;
        unsigned char payloadLen = 0;
        unsigned char lastCommand = 0;

        bcmInit();
        NRFReset();
        NRFInit();
        NRFRXMode();
        NRFOn();

        while(1){

                NRFStatus = NRF_readRegister(NRF_REGISTER_STATUS);

        if(NRFStatus & NRF_BIT_RX_DR || (NRF_readRegister(NRF_REGISTER_FIFO_STATUS) & 1) == 0){// Check Status And FIFO Registers For Waiting Payload
            NRF_setBit(NRF_REGISTER_STATUS, NRF_BIT_RX_DR);// Clear RX Bit In Status Register
                        payloadLen = NRF_readCommand(NRF_COMMAND_R_RX_PL_WID);
                        if(payloadLen <= 32){// Check Payload Length, Flush If Invalid
                                NRF_readPayload(payloadLen);
                                if(((NRFStatus >> 1) & 7) == NRF_REM_PIPE){// Check Which Pipe Has Data
                                        if(lastCommand != NRFpayload[0]){// Temporary Fix To Prevent Commands Being Run More Than Once Per Keypress
                                                lastCommand = NRFpayload[0];
                                                switch(lastCommand){
                                                        case 1:
                                                                system("wakeonlan xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx");// Wake PC
                                                                break;
                            case 2:
                                system("ssh [email protected] sudo shutdown -P 0");// Shutdown PC
                                break;
                                                        case 3:
                                                                system("sudo reboot");// Reboot Raspberry Pi
                                                                break;
                                                        case 4:
                                                                system("minidlnad -R");// Rebuild MiniDLNA Database
                                                                break;
                                                        case 5:
                                                                system("lights.sh --on");// Turn Lights On
                                                                break;
                                                        case 6:
                                                                system("lights.sh --off");// Turn Lights Off
                                                                break;
                                                        case 7:
                                                                system("lights.sh --brightness=50");// Adjust Light Intensity
                                                                break;
                                                        case 8:
                                                                system("garage.sh --close");// Close Garage Door
                                system("mysql -uroot -proot HomeAudit -e 'INSERT INTO AutomationLog (timestamp) values (UNIX_TIMESTAMP(now()));'");
                                                                break;
                                                        case 9:
                                                                system("sos.sh --panic");// SOS -- Get Help
                                                                break;
                                                        case 10:
                                                                system("implode.sh");// Destroy Files
                                                                break;
                            /* ........................... */

                                                        default:

                            case 0: ;// Part Of The Temporary Fix To Prevent Duplicate Keypress Events. On Keyup "0" Is Sent From Remote
                                                }
                                        }
                                }
                        }else{
                                NRF_writeCommand(NRF_COMMAND_FLUSH_RX);
                        }
                }
        }
}
PIC16F628A 
#pragma config FOSC = INTOSCIO  // Internal oscillator - I/O on RA6 and RA7
#pragma config WDTE = OFF       // Watchdog timer off
#pragma config PWRTE = ON       // Power-up timer enabled
#pragma config MCLRE = OFF      // Disable master clear
#pragma config BOREN = OFF      // Disable brown-out detection
#pragma config LVP = OFF        // Disable low voltage program - free RB4
#pragma config CPD = OFF        // No EEPROM protection
#pragma config CP = OFF         // No code protection

#include <xc.h>
#include "NRFComm.h"
#include "NRFConfig.h"
#include "NRFFunctions.h"

#define _XTAL_FREQ 4000000

#define NRF_MOSI RA0
#define NRF_CSN RA1
#define NRF_CE RA2
#define NRF_SCK RA6
#define NRF_MISO RA7

unsigned char newKeypress = 0;
static volatile unsigned char waste = 0;

void nrf(void){
    unsigned char NRFStatus = 0;

    while(newKeypress){
        NRFStatus = NRF_readRegister(NRF_REGISTER_STATUS);

        if(NRFStatus & NRF_BIT_TX_DS){
            NRF_setBit(NRF_REGISTER_STATUS, NRF_BIT_TX_DS);
            newKeypress = 0;
            NRFOff();
        }

        if(NRFStatus & NRF_BIT_MAX_RT){
            NRF_setBit(NRF_REGISTER_STATUS, NRF_BIT_MAX_RT);
            NRF_writeCommand(NRF_COMMAND_FLUSH_TX);
            newKeypress = 0;
            NRFOff();
        }
    }
}

void interrupt isr(void){
    if(RBIF){
        waste = PORTB; // Must read or write portb to clear IOC condition
        RBIF = 0;
    }
}

// @TODO Many Bug Fixes. Add Modifier Keys RA3-RA5
void main(void) {
    unsigned char i = 0;
    unsigned char keysPressed = 0;

    OPTION_REG = 0b01001000;
    INTCON = 0b10001000;
    CMCON = 0b00000111;//Disable comparator

    TRISA = 0b10111000;
    TRISB = 0b11110000;
    PORTA = 0b00000000;
    PORTB = 0b00000000;

    NRFInit();
    NRFTXMode();
    NRFOff();

    asm("sleep");
    asm("nop");

    while(1){
        if(!newKeypress){
            TRISB = 240 | ~(1 << i);

            if((PORTB >> 4) != 15){
                NRFOn();
                NRFpayload[0] = (PORTB & 240) | (TRISB & 15);
                NRF_writePayload(NRF_COMMAND_W_TX_PAYLOAD, 1);
                NRFTransmit();
                newKeypress = 1;
                keysPressed++;
                nrf();
            }

            if(++i == 4){
                i=0;
                if(keysPressed == 0){
                    NRFOn();
                    newKeypress = 1;
                    NRFpayload[0] = 0;
                    NRF_writePayload(NRF_COMMAND_W_TX_PAYLOAD, 1);// Temporary Fix. Allows RX To Detect Keydown And Keyup, Messy Debounce Function Essentially.
                    NRFTransmit();
                    nrf();
                    NRFOff();
                    TRISB = 0b11110000;
                    asm("sleep");
                    asm("nop");
                }
                keysPressed = 0;
            }
        }
    }
}

description.text:
This is a set of components for a modular model paint holder. This was designed primarily for 26mm bottles (Army Painter, Model Color, Etc). The shelf itself is 1/4" MDF from a home supply store (roughly 6mm thickness). The shelf pieces are 40mm x 562mm, and the step height between shelves is 28mm. These dimensions are up to you, since the components and other accessories are modular (136mm wide).

Parts included are:

  1. 4 bottle holder (136mm)
  2. 3 bottle holder (102mm) (3 bottle holder allows for an offset on every other shelf)
  3. Brush holder (136mm)
  4. Card holder (136mm)

The card holder makes for a convenient spot to hold a card that represents the miniature being painted. Replace these with extra paint bottle holders if not needed.

Glue the pieces together with cyanoacrylate, and clip into place on the MDF shelf. See attached sketchup drawing and photos for assembly hints.

title: M6 Extruder Bolt Guide for Flexible Filament

description.text:
M6 threaded headless bolt for using flexible filament with an MK8 all metal extruder. Used to reduce risk of the filament binding up.

Notes

A low layer height is recommended to preserve the screw threads (I used 0.1 mm). This was designed for use with 1.75mm filaments, it will not work with 2.5 or 3 mm filaments (the hole diameter is close to 2.55mm). Should be printable as-is without supports. I have only done test prints using a 0.4mm nozzle and a 0.8mm wall/shell thickness, other options were not tested.

You will likely have to remove the metal feed base to install the guide. I have not been able to fully test this myself as I do not have flexible filament available.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ldDbPTlpw8Q

UPDATE December 22, 2013
Big thank you to everyone who have supported our project! At our own studio, we were able to raise $700AUD which is equivalent to 28,000 Pesos! It was donated to Red Cross Australia. This project will always be open so please everyone share your pins!

UPDATE December 4, 2013
Hello all. Thank you for all those who have downloaded our pin. Please share with us your versions and hand-painted pins! We would love to see them and share them!

To help the victims of one of the strongest storms ever recorded to hit the Philippines, we are raising funds to donate to the Red Cross for Christmas through the potentials of open-source design and 3d printing. Instead of doing a one-off donation, we hope this small project will create a ripple and amplify our intentions a hundred fold. We love pins! In light of this disaster, we have designed a pin that celebrates the Filipino word, "ÃÂbayanihan"ÃÂ referring to the unified spirit and actions of the community to achieve a specific goal. It is our hope that with your help, by printing and raising money, we would be able to raise more funds compared to our small studio if we do it alone. Think Global, Act Local. With no secondary support structures and very small in scale, our pins were designed to be easily printed by any FDM (Fused Deposition Modelling) 3d printer around the world. They are printed using 1.75mm White PLA filaments. They are then assembled, painted and finished by hand. We will provide the printers settings we used to print as a guide. So for one day (or a week), get involved and stop printing Yoda heads, owls, iPhone cases and little vases and print these fund-raising pins for the victims of Haiyan. Share your iterations! Share your printed versions! For more information please visit our project page @
http://www.superscale.com.au/portfolio/3-stars-a-sun/ Follow and like our 3d printing studio MIMAW @
https://www.facebook.com/mimaw.workshop Important Notes:
  • If you would like to participate and raise funds by printing your own 3d printed pins, you do not need to send us the money you have raised. Please feel free to donate them to whatever charity that will help the Typhoon Haiyan victims but please let us know how much money you have raised so we can see how successful this type of fund raising can be! Email us @ [email protected]
They are printed using 1.75mm White PLA filaments.  They are then assembled, painted and finished by hand.  Please down load the "3 Stars & a Sun Print Guide.pdf" file to use our settings as a guide.

title: Direct Geared Belted Extruder 1,75mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Direct Geared Belted Extruder 1,75mm (v1)

This model has been superseeded for a V2.

New model has been turned 90 degrees: Direct Geared Belted Extruder V2 (1,75mm)

If you are looking for a bowden version, you should go see my Belted Extruder v.3 for 1.75 instead.

Key features
  • Compact highly accurate, easy to use and -install Direct Drive Geared Belted Extruder for all 1,75mm filaments.
  • Gearings 1:3.75
  • Weight including motor: 316g - This is inclusive all gears, belt, screws, nuts etc..
    Please note that a standard normal Nema 17 weights 290g in itself, so 316g is VERY light
  • Only Quality items used to for Higher longelevity and Accuracy.
  • No exotic, hard to find expensive parts used.
  • Set and Forget Idler system - try it! :)
  • Prusa compatible mount hole spacing.
  • Silent running due to belt operation.
  • Mount holes for Optional usage of Expansions.
Expansions options
  • Option to mount sensors or other expansion behind hotend.
  • Cooling solution can be mounted on Expansion slots instead of on hotend
  • Opton to mount cable management, Motor-cover, fans and other expansions next to motor.
Nema 17 used
  • I am using Nema 17 "pancake" as in flat model.
  • Manufacturer Part Number: 17HM08-1204S
    0.9deg Nema 17 Stepper Motor 1.2A 11Ncm/15.6oz.in 42x42x20mm
    I found it on german ebay.
  • You can reuse whatever Nema 17 you might have, but using a smaller motor dramatically decreases the weight.

Usage Requirment

While this Direct-Drive Belted Extruder 1,75mm (v1) has standard hole mount spacing of 23mm center to center of the mount holes, you are going to do one of the following 3 options:

  1. Use a modified x-Carriage, which I'll provide soon.
  2. Remove 1-2mm of the top of your existing Carriage.
  3. Use a 8-9mm spacer-plate to put between your existing carriage and the extruder.

Buy one?

I am selling these. Also just the metal parts. Drop me a message if interested. I live in Denmark and can ship for DKkr 35 in Denmark, but let me know where you live, and we'll see.

3D model and files?

I do not offer up the extruder in other fileformats than STL, but you can see the model on MyHub on Autodesk's servers.

Printer:

My Crossbot design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm max

Infill:

25% or more

Notes:
I have provided 2 models:
  • 1 with support and 1 without for people who'd like to setup support on their own.
Other Settings
  • 3 Borders/Perimeters.
  • 3 Top/Bottom -layers or more.
  • I have printed in PLA and PETG without resize modifiers in slizer. If you use ABS you might need to enlarge your object in the slizer.
Remove supports colored red here. Remove supports colored red here.

I used Autodesk Fision 360

There is a common misconception that Autodesk Fusion 360 costs money, but it truely is totally free to use for private people and small businesses and not just students and teachers.

Once installe you are asked to accept the licens and just put in you are private person or small business as appropriate. Once a year you have to re-accept the licens.

Also check out their free app for phones and tablets which can be used to view and share your items.

Bill Of Materials
  • 60GT-2 Pulley
  • 16GT-2 or 20GT-2 Pulley.
  • E3D Hobbed Bolt - Hobb-Goblin-8mm-Shaft.
  • 172-GT2 Belt.
  • 0-1x m6 Push-Fitting for 1.75mm filament.
  • 2x 20mm steel springs. 1-1.2mm thick.
  • 3x 608 bearings. 8x22x7 - Type doesn't matter.
  • Various m3 nuts, screws and spacers - Details below
Detailed Screwn/Nut BOM
  • 13-17x M3 nuts (if using cable management or motor-covers)
  • 4x m3 spacers - Fasten Motor
  • 4x m3 8mm - Expansions bar.
  • 4x m3 10mm - Fasten Motor.
  • 3x m3 16mm - Hotend Fastener and Idler.
  • 2x m3 25mm - Idler and Spring Frame joints.
  • 2x m3 50mm - Socket Head Screws, Partially Threaded.
  • 4x m4 - Lock-nuts
<h5>Addons</h5>

Everything for my Belted Extruders, including Mounting brackets can be found in the my Collection: Belted Extruders by Dintid

Addons are trickling in, so hit follow or just check back now and then :)

Insert m3 nuts into the Insert Screw in the m3 50mm screws untill they are flush with the bottom of the Mounting hole measurements. Extensions-plate and holespacing measurements. Distance measurements to build Extensions and Fan-Shrouds etc. Metal parts-pack - Please note that there are extras of the smallest sizes to make up for any accidents. <h3>Calibrate Steps/mm</h3>

A few stepper examples. Remember to do a proper measurement yourself. I have rounded the numbers up/down.

When using:

  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 0.9degree motor = 2050 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 0.9 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 510 steps/mm

  • two for a corner bottom

you may print screw from this link http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Need

  • 4 for M4 x 45mm socket head cap screw

comments.text: I used one of these parts in order to make a DOCK for a Kobalt battery [actually several of them] to connect wiring to an e-bike.  The batteries inside the Lowe's sold battery pack are pretty decent for the money.  Rather than HARVEST all of those batteries (one pack at a time), I was able to use this to create DOCKS for wiring directly to the batteries.  In effect, making the battery pack modular.  MY first print printed two (2 designs here are similar and I couldnt see the difference, so I printed both).   One misprinted initially and was 3/8 inch shorter than the other.  This turned out NOT to be an issue.  So in a redesign of the "DOCK" one could cut back on the height and save both material and time.  [I have not done so, since my design skills are lacking at this point.]  A HUGE Thankyou to the original designer.  You dont realize how EASY you made this portion of my project.  This is my first 3D printed object.  And it wont be my last.
comments.author: Nejpski

comments.text: Thanks so much for posting. I'm in the process of making this. So far I made the Kobalt side. It is slick. The battery is a good fit but doesn't quite slide in far enough to lock. I'm going to do a little adjustment with a dremel tool to get it to lock. I printed on a Makerbot 2. Standard 0.03mm res 100% infill. If I printed it higher res. it might have locked.

description.text: This is a draft of our team's maze giveaway. We want to find a plastic cover for the mazes. The maze is designed to work with a 0.177" BB. Our team name and number is embossed on the back of the maze. I uploaded the ipt, igs, and stp files for the part. If anyone does modify it for their team could you let me know. My current thought on the plastic cover is either to buy some that I can glue to the maze - or pause the print in the middle after their is a spot for the cover and then continue printing with the idea that the material will print around the cover. I have not tried this yet - but will change the description if it works for me.
Just print and go. I printed this on the team's MakerBot 2 with no fill and no support, 10%fill, and 4 shells.

Print flat, I don't know why the STL output with the models standing up from Fusion 360. The top side edge of the rounded pieces have a slight fillet.

L-Brackets = 60mm x 100mm
T-Brackets = 100mm x 100mm
Short T Brackets = 100mm x 60mm
Short L Brackets = 60mm x 60mm
Long L Brackets = 100mm x 100mm
Long T Brackets = 180mm x 100mm

You'll need to mirror the rounded regular L Brackets for any right side joints. It's set up for Left now. All of the others are universal.

The new shorter brackets are intended for use with 2028 aluminum corner brackets.

description.text:
Yet another remix of emmetts geared bearing. I have wrapped the original item in a module() with parameters, and used it as a subassembly of my adapter plate. Wit the item wrapped like this, it becomes easy to insert it into an SCAD thing wherever bearings might be needed.

The adapter plate itself was designed simply by measuring the spool with calipers and getting the dimensions.
